div.p: INTENSELY HIGH PART of a LANDSCAPE, TYPICALLY WITH STEEP SIDES.
1. The general term for a mountain of any kind, large or small, is shān 山.

2. Yuè 岳／嶽 refers is a positive way to one of the great mountains of China, and the word typically functions as the head word in a noun phrase, as in 五岳. (Note that obviously in proper names and designations of titles (e.g. the title sì yuè 四岳 ) the two characters are not interchangeable.)
3. Fù 阜 refers to a large non-rocky mountain with an elevated plain on top.
4. Ā 阿 refers to a very large non-rocky mountan with an elevated plain on top.
5. Qiū 丘 refers to a small non-rocky earth mound.
6. Yuán 原 can refer to the highlands and is marginal in this group.

7. Lǐng 嶺, later sometimes written 領, is not a post-Han word, as many dictionaries might lead one to suppose, but the word is very rare in pre-Han times. The word refers to mountains as forming a series, often connoting a road along the ridge.
GEOGRAPHY 6. 地面上由土石構成的隆起部分。
巒，小而易登之山，漢代起可泛指山，使用頻率較低。
岳，專稱 “ 四岳 ” 或 “ 五岳 ” ，後作高山通稱。
領，山體有道路回繞的山。
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages
《說文段注》“渾言”“析言”在漢語詞義研究中的意義 "Shuowen Duan zhu" "hun yan" "xi yan" zai Hanyu ci yi yanjiu zhong de yiyi 杭州大學學報 Hangzhou daxue xuebao

note.p: collis is an elevation in opposition to a surrounding plain.
clivus is a sloping plain forming a gentle elevation.
tumulus refers to a typically striking natural or artificial elevation.
grumus can only refer to an artificial elevation.

bibl.title: 古代文化詞異集類辨考 Gudai wenhua ci yi ji lei bian kao

note.p: 1. Li3ng 嶺 is indeed the uppermost part of a sha1n 山.

bibl.title: SYNONYMES FRANÇOIS, LEURS DIFFÉRENTES SIGNIFICATIONS, ET LE CHOIX QU'IL EN FAUT FAIRE Pour parler avec justesse

sense.def: (artificial) hill or pile (even of corpses) 京丘

entry.def: Yuán 原 can refer to the highlands and is marginal in this group.

sense.def: (live) in the (craggy) mountains or among the cliffs

entry.def: The general term for a mountain of any kind, large or small, is shān 山.

sense.def: mountain of rock; mountain (occasionally not of rock, and even man-made)
substantial mountain, but not one of the five big ones
level mountain ridge ERYA: 山脊岡 The spine of a hill

entry.def: Yuè 岳／嶽 refers is a positive way to one of the great mountains of China. (Note that obviously in proper names and designations of titles (e.g. the title sì yuè 四岳) the two characters are not interchangeable.)

Yuè 岳／嶽 refers is a positive way to one of the great mountains of China. (Note that obviously in proper names and designations of titles (e.g. the title sì yuè 四岳) the two characters are not interchangeable.)

sense.def: name of one of the five sacred mountains
name of a mountain; in 崑崙
name of a mountain; in:崑崙
mountain recess; corner or bend of a hill

entry.def: Lǐng 嶺, later sometimes written 領, is not a post-Han word, as many dictionaries might lead one to suppose, but the word is very rare in pre-Han times. The word refers to mountains as forming a series, often connoting a road along the ridge.

sense.def: mountain 五嶺 refers to a place characterised by five interleinkted mountain peaks
mountain ridge; also: sharp pointed mountain
mountain top; summit of mountain (SHI): 巔
mountain with large top and without a very large base

entry.def: Ā 阿 refers to a very large non-rocky mountan with an elevated plain on top.

sense.def: mountain range which may be passed by a regular road. (Standardly written 嶺)
the Five Mountains 指東岳 泰山 、南岳 衡山 、西岳 華山 、北岳 恒山 、中岳 嵩山 。
